description: From Middle English appetit, from Old French apetit (French appétit), from Latin appetitus, from appetere (“to strive after, long for”); ad + petere (“to seek”). See petition, and compare with appetence.

entries.meaning: Desire to eat food or consume drink.
examples: And I return with an excellent appetite. There can be no question, my dear Watson, of the value of exercise before breakfast.

entries.meaning: Any strong desire; an eagerness or longing.
The desire for some personal gratification, either of the body or of the mind.
